reviewText:
Bland, limited & repetitive gameplay is what you can expect from Sid's Ace Patrol. I really tried to enjoy this (I put in the time!), but it has none of the 'one-more-turn' addictiveness of his other games.

So why is it so bad you ask?

Each map looks almost identical, graphics look like direct port from mobile platform, the mission types you can count on one hand & the game itself is very short covering 24 missions across 4 campaigns. They can go quick too! You do not feel there is any progression as you go through as the game centres around your score; having little in the way of feeling like you are winning a war. There is no territory to defend or conquer instead you choose from 3 random missions then up to 4 pilots to progress through each level. Pilot & plane upgrades are rewarded as you proceed through your game, but only really make it easier to win & that isn't really a strong point when the 'Legend' difficulty is not really very challenging. Legend (besides boosting your score) just makes it more frustrating than anything else since the opposing pilots get big stats boosts making it take a painfully long time to shoot them down yet much easier for you to be shot down.

Tactically you will find many dogfights are reduced to both of you flying around in circles for multiple moves until the AI decides to fly out giving you an opening to attack. You can try different tactics but it always comes back to 'circling' from my experience. Once you get behind someone it is very hard for them to get away (unless they're an Ace pilot), and likewise when the roles are reversed. It makes the first few turns of your engagment most important, but then very predictable after that. To add to this, I also couldn't play this on my old PC with ATI graphics as it wouldn't render the display, showing all white, so I have only been able to play recently since I got my new PC with NVidia graphics.

All said & done, I can't help but to ask myself why Sid would put his name on such a sub-par game, let alone make a sequel! Also milking it further by charging almost twice as much locally in AU @ $8.99 instead of US @ $4.99 (still well overpriced for what you get if you ask me).

Very disappointing! :(

Sid Meier's Ace Patrol uses the power of the personal computer to do the same thing.\n\nSid Meier's Ace Patrol is a simple one or two player game simulating air combat in World War I. reviewText:
This little gem is actually quite intereresting. Made for smart phones and Tablets originally but ported to the PC and beamed into our collective HD using the magic that is STEAM Ace Patrol is about two things. Biplane Hex Combat and more importantly fun.

Gameplay is basically this. You pick a nation (UK, France, Imperial Germany or America!)  and each nation has a selecton of randomly generated pilots with aeroplanes of the era and you dogfight the enemy using a turn based hex combat system. Your squadron can have up to four Pilots who fly a series of randomly generated missions over four different offensives against NPC pilots who like your own can be captured or forced temporary out of the war to repair their damaged crates. Both friendly and enemy squadron Pilots unlock RPG-esqe skills, upgrades for their planes and learn special manauvers that give them the upper hand in combat. Oh and as the offensive progresses so does air technology for both sides. You might be flying easy one moment and then the enemy has a fancier crate with another set of wings and a bigger gun to keep you on your toes!

Combat itself is pretty simple, get a good shot under or behind the enemy plane whilst not exposing yourself to the dangers of their wingmans guns or AA gun fire. You are graded with a score system that is tied to the general STEAM achivements and online leaderboard for said game. To increase the score obviously you'll have to ratchet up the difficulty level (or be lucky enough to get a Pilot with the DOUBLE SCORE ability).

The other feature to keep you playing again is once you complete a Offensive with a certain nation the first time you unlock famous WW1 Ace Pilots with their own biplane livery schemes.

Bugs wise I've only encountered one and that sometimes you have some trouble clicking on a hex, this gets really fiddly when your Pilot has a million manuvers and you really don't want to select the FORCE LANDING one. I expect this is to do with it being more of a Tablet game really. Also, some of the art assets are slightly bland (Don't get excited about seeing the Offensive Victory screen more than once)  despite the fact they did their best locked more or less in a single location.

Is it worth buying though? sure, why not if you want a addictive but slighty short turn based aeroplane game . But for the best value get it in a Sale and make sure you pick up the rather decent WW2 Pacific Campaign sequal at the same time.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Ace Patrol is a fun, although highly unrealistic at times, turn-based strategy game set during The Great War (aka World War I). How much you enjoy it, however, depends on several factors, all of which shall be discussed in this review.

The first thing many gamers on Steam will notice is that the graphics aren't particularly high-res and the options menu within the game is severely limited. You can't even set the game's resolution and as far as I can tell, there's no anti-aliasing at all.

The reason for this is because SMAP was originally an iOS title.

What's the difference between the iOS app and the PC game? The mobile game is free, but requires that you pay for additional content. The PC version demands payment up front, but there no additional fees, optional or otherwise. The iOS version also uses a touch-screen interface as well, while the PC uses the mouse.

The game's audio is quite nice, especially the sound effects. Whenever you move one of your planes you hear the associated propeller-driven engine noise. It even changes depending on damage or what maneuver you're attempting to pull off.

The music fits the game, although I turned it off. This wasn't because it was bad, but because I generally dislike background music in games.

Unfortunately, your pilots' voices (the few times they speak) are sometimes weird or just plain buggy. One of my German pilots had a voice that sounded like someone had slowed down an old tape recording. It was amusing, but somewhat creepy at the same time.

The gameplay is standard turn-based fare, with some RPG elements tossed in. While in combat, your planes move over a hex-based battlefield, and have to keep an eye on their location. If they pass over an enemy base, for instance, anti-aircraft guns will fire at them. Fly into the clouds and you'll have temporary cover.

Your position also determines when you can fire at the enemy and how much damage you can potentially do. Attacking an enemy from a higher altitude generally inflicts more damage on them, just as lining up shots while on their tail. Likewise, trying to attack an enemy while head-on or from a lower altitude does less damage and exposes you to return fire.

The RPG elements come into play by leveling up your pilots. They can gain rank and medals, including ace status. If you win missions and have less than 50% damage on any pilot, you gain a bonus that can be applied to any pilot. These bonuses improve weapons, flying, and armor.

After a certain number of kills, each pilot gains a callsign, which denotes a  special ability, some of which are offensive and other defensive. Examples of offensive callsigns include Deadeye" (long-range attack and better accuracy) or "Executioner" (potential to kill enemy during first attack) while some defensive callsigns are "Lucky" (anti-aircraft guns do no damage to you) or "Grease Monkey" (repairs plane faster).

Each airplane also has its own stats

Score: 8.5 / 10

A fantastic title that reminds me highly of Fantasy Flight Games' X-Wing Miniatures series, Ace Patrol is a turn based strategy game focused on WW1 air combat. Each side takes turns performing various maneuvers with a handful of aircraft from America, France, Germany and Britain. Most missions are simple, ranging from one on one ace combat, reconnaisance, bombing and zepplin attacks.

Pilots add another layer of strategy as they level up with successful kills. Each level allows the player to choose from three different sets of maneuvers for that specific pilot. Should the player keep damage levels above 50% in a scenario they will gain a part unlock to attach to a plane. This comes in the form of accuracy, damage, speed and maneuverability upgrades.

All in all, a wonderful game with high replayability. Recommended at any price!

reviewText:
Delightful turn-based air combat. Every turn is an agonising choice as you choose between maneuvers. The game mechanic of trading altitude for speed and advanced maneuvers is breathtaking in its clarity, simplicity, and plausible authenticity.

The early days of air combat lead to a game of jousting and attack runs, both sides clawing for altitude and position, weaving in and out of clouds and flak zones, trying to line up a shot or trick the enemy into lining themselves up for another pilot's power dive kill shot. Taking to the air knowing you're facing a supremely skilled enemy Ace is a daunting prospect as he dances his bird across the sky, crossing your engagement lines in a lightning sprint and performing daring aerobatics to bring himself up into your squadron's six, but even the best pilot can find himself hard pressed if he lets himself get caught at low altitude, exhausted by constant high-gee flying.

It's a light, tight, satisfying game that shows its mobile roots on the surface but the underlying design shows an understanding of what makes a game work that dwarfs most AAA releases.

reviewText:
Note: Summary at the bottom of the review.

Ace Patrol is the first of the (currently two) Ace Patrol games. While its successor tackles WW2, this takes on WW1 where the strategy involves maneuvering your plane into the best possible position to shoot down the enemy. As you progress, nev maneuvers, planes and improvements become avaliable. The game is a casual one, but while you cannot expect much depth or complexity from it, you can expect it to be a fun pack-up-and-play game. And in all honesty, how many WW1 Air Combat TBS games are there out there? The originality of it alone deserves mention!
Another thing that should be mentioned is that your squadron will have female combat pilots. While I applaud the inclusion of female pilots on the principle of it being awesome, I am puzzled why Firaxis neglected to include an option to disable them for those that want to preserve some historical accuracy.

Pro:
*Fun little TBS air-combat game.
*Includes female pilots, yay!
*Casual pick-up-and-play style.

Con:
*Lacking in depth and complexity.
*No option to turn off female pilots for those wanting historical accuracy.
*Not a lot of customization when it comes to graphics, etc.

Summary:
Ace Patrol is worth its asking price, so long as you do not expect a great amount of depth, complexity or historical accuracy. That being said, it is a fun game set in a very interesting era of aviation! 5/10 -Recomended.

reviewText:
The first thing I have to say is do not be put off by this game because it's a port from the IPHONE. AGAIN I REPEAT DON'T BE PUT OFF BECAUSE GAME IS A PORT FROM THE IPHONE!

Now that I have told you that, let me tell you why you need to get this game if you like taticle turb based strategy games such as Frozen Synapse where you attempt to get into the best situation possible so that you may obliterate your enemy, than this game is for you. Here are the basics. You control a squad of 4 WW1 airplanes. You do missions ranging from shoot down all enemy pilots to protect your recon plane. You must than issue orders to your pilots based on their abilites and manuvers to complete the mission. Use each of them to cover the other. Deal with altitude, cloud cover and evasion. In other words, the combat is deep and satisfying. Missions can take anywere from 5 minutes to 15 minutes depending on how you play and how risky or safe you play.

How much gameplay is there? I've played 3 hours so far, still British (which is the first nation you get to play as) and just started the 3rd level out of 5 (I believe) After that you get to pick the next nation you play as which has different mission types, locals and planes.

The graphics suit the game just fine, a bit cartoony but not over the top cartoony. The planes have nice modles as does the ground. But your not playing this game for the graphics, your playing this game for the combat. Again, think games like Frozen Synapse or Advanced Wars mixed with the Hex Based grid system of Civilization V mixed in with Altitude, upgradable manuvers, cloud cover and hours of fun and strategy.

The game never feels cheep when your plane is getting shot up. More than likely there was a way to forgo the situtation you are in, but you can undo turns, keep going and get your self out. Some missions only allow 1 pillot while others require all 4. But you have to manage your pilots. Each pilot has a different skill set of manuvers ranging from rolls, loops, ace moves and many more and even a special perk such as being able to shoot from farther away, copy all plane upgrades or escape from POW camps. So you have to look at the mission your going to do and pick the best pilot(s) for the job.

There's still so much that I didn't cover in this review because I havn't even touched the surface of this game. Am I filling this review full of BS and lies? No. This is all true and better than I can explain. Should you get this game? If you like deep tacticle strategy games, than yes.

reviewText:
Heavily simplified civ game

Ace patrol is about unit tactics.

In the campaign you start with four pilots as they face off their foes in World War one. You can customise your first pilot's voice and portrait who will go on the first mission. Each pilot command their own plane. As you progress through the game you can unlock new planes, which each have varying stats. Your pilots will also level up during the game. As they do you can select an ability for them to learn which varies between their movement during play. If you meet certain requirements, you can unlock perks for pilots after each mission which includes improving accuracy and defence. Each plane has a set amount of health. When your pilots get shot down, they remain unavailable in later missions until they are released. Injured pilots may also be unavailable in later missions as well. You get to choose different mission types in campaign:  defence and attack. In defence missions, you basically have to defend a certain building or units from being destroyed by the enemy. In attack missions, you need to bomb/destroy a particular building or unit. As you win one country's campaign you unlock another one (you start off with playing as the British)

Combat is turn based. You generally select your units and move them on the highlited pads. Certain pads may glow red, indicating that you will shoot at the enemy plane when you move there. You will be provided with the amount of damage you will do to the enemy plane. Furthermore, you can only shoot at plane from the front and to the side only, so you need to turn around if enmy planes are behind you.

There isn't much music to this game. The title screen music is like classical 'Civ' games, but there is no tracks during gameplay. Your pilots may say a few words, but they are forgettable anyway.


If you enjoy basic civ game which only focuses on unit combat then you may like this game. If your expecting a 'civilisation' game, you will DEFINATELY be dissapointed.

reviewText:
Fun, little game I have very fond memories about two specific titles from the past - Over The Reich and it's sequel Achtung! Spitfire. Ace Patrol does look a bit like those games, but with more colorful/kid-friendly approach.  After a few hours of gameplay I can honestly say, It's not even close to level of grand those aformentioned games represented.

Ace Patrol feels like a mobile game (and it is a mobile game too). Gameplay is a mostly fun, turn-based dogfighting with light rpg elements. Scale is a first dissapointment -  you won't command more than 4 planes at once. Most of the time, missions involve two or three of your pilots. That's just sad - no chance for grand strategy battles. Rpg elements are barebones. There's no real way to customize your pilots - you just make them better and add new skills. The same with new planes - every time you get a new one, it's better then the previous.  If you hope for a long campaign - you can finish all missions (diveded into 6 offensives) in around 2h. Single mission takes around 5-10 minutes to be completed.  Offcourse the main goal of the game is to win the war on the highest difficulty setting, but most of us, will be perfectly happy with medium. Ace Patrol can be punishing at times. You are not obliged to win every mission, but failures will cost you.... points. Yes, it seems that Ace Patrol is more of a score attack game. Sure, shot down pilots will end up in hospital for a while or be captured and put into POW camp for the rest of the offensive. Also, failing missions will change the final outcome of the offensive. Nevertheless, it's all about your final score, not about ranking up your pilots or enjoyable mission objectives.
After finishing the game with one of the factions, I'm not really interested in playing it again. Factions don't really differ from one another,  so replaying the game as Americans or French changes nothing. Also, i don't think there's enough variety in mission objectives or rpg elements. It's just so basic and bare-bones.

reviewText:
Ace Patrol is a fun little hex-based air combat game set during World War I. It is important to keep in mind that this is a casual game. The gameplay is not especially deep or complicated, but that is not necessarily a bad thing. It is easy to pick up and play through a few quick missions if you don‚Äôt want to get sucked into a full-blown, drawn-out strategy game like Civilization V or XCOM. (Not to say that the gameplay of Ace Patrol isn't incredibly addictive, because it is.)

Missions take just a few minutes to complete, and there are roughly twenty-four missions per campaign (There is one campaign for each of the four playable nations). During a mission, you maneuver your little squadron around the playing field to complete the objective, be it shooting down enemy aircraft, destroying supply convoys or escorting reconnaissance planes. But it isn‚Äôt enough to simply shoot down other planes as quickly as possible by selecting the move that gives the most damage‚Ä¶ doing so might put your plane directly into the enemies' line of fire. Instead, you will need to decide the best course of action of how to destroy the enemy planes and still bring your guys back (relatively) undamaged.

Ace Patrol is quite fun, however, there are a couple of downsides. The graphics are so-so (I find they have their charm). And even though there are ‚Äúcampaigns‚Äù, there is no storyline or narrative, which is a bit disappointing.
